Игра 'War of the Three Kingdoms' – это захватывающая стратегическая игра, погружающая в эпоху китайской истории. Игрокам предстоит взять на себя роль одного из военачальников и бороться за власть над землями. Геймплей строится на управлении ресурсами, развитии городов, наборе и обучении войск, а также стратегическом планировании военных кампаний. Дипломатия играет немаловажную роль, позволяя заключать союзы и плести интриги, чтобы перехитрить соперников.

Особенно впечатляет масштабность карт и реалистичная система ведения боя. Разнообразие юнитов и тактических приемов обеспечивает глубину игрового процесса. Графика хоть и не поражает воображение, но вполне соответствует жанру и не отвлекает от стратегического планирования.

Несмотря на некоторую сложность освоения на первых порах, игра предлагает увлекательный и многогранный опыт, требующий от игрока стратегического мышления и умения адаптироваться к изменяющимся обстоятельствам. Любителям исторических стратегий определенно стоит обратить внимание. Возможно, игра требует небольших улучшений в интерфейсе, но в целом оставляет положительное впечатление.

12 hours is the maximum amount of time I can play without recharging, including idle time. Before I ramble on, let me first list—briefly—the problems I’ve found so far with the Steam version of Legends of the Three Kingdoms (a.k.a. Sanguosha):

1. It is a 1-to-1 port of the Chinese mobile side-server “一将成名” (formerly the 10th-anniversary edition). No proper PC full-screen support.
2. The newbie tutorial is still the one I saw five years ago—wordy, draggy, and with no finer explanations added.
3. The UI has been updated to something uglier, yet the tutorial still shows the old layout; enemy-indicator arrows point at the wrong places.
4. BGM often drops even though the game is never minimised.
5. As a half-web product, front-end responsiveness is mediocre: when the connection is bad you can spam the “End Turn” button and the server will accept every click.
6. The timer in the “new-player login-length” mission freezes; you must restart the client to refresh it.
7. Friends list, chat, and other non-gameplay functions are level-gated; there is no way to skip the tutorial.
8. AI is brain-dead: it cannot even tell loyalists from rebels; the “traitor” idles until the lord is dying; skill usage is catastrophic—it does not know the correct order to play vanilla cards, let alone combine skills.
9. Ranked queues are so empty that the matchmaker stuffs bots in, turning a sure win into a clown-fiesta defeat. No opt-out button. If there are not enough rookies, the game feeds paying customers brain-dead AIs and calls it “fun”. Even as a VIP I cannot squeeze any joy out of it.


Since I started in 2012 this IP has rolled downhill non-stop. Same rules, same cards, same modes—only the gacha banners, power-creep generals and a few odd mechanics change. They keep spawning OL edition, Mobile, Global, 10th-Anniversary (this one), “Happy” mini-game, We-chat mini, and a dozen obscure channel-servers—all aimed at milking the same cow dry.

“Maybe they want A/B testing or segmented users?”—if any, very little; real bug-testing does not exist, because every build has carried the same catastrophic bugs for years, some still unfixed and unmentioned.


Monetisation is built to bleed, not sustain.

Money comes from two faucets: generals and skins.

1. Power is locked behind pay-walls. Free players grind months or years for one meta general.
2. Once you finally get it they:
	- Release a strictly-better cash general,
	- Lower your general’s pick-rate through opaque “random” selection,
	- Rig the card deck so your key cards appear below probability.

3. Skill is meaningless when raw numbers crush you; unpaid players are Zhuge Liang six-sortie-ing from Qishan—great ambition, zero capital.

Skins sell even harder—some borderline-erotic female skins out-earn the strongest general of the season. Yet:

- Quality is uneven and homogenised (AI-art suspicion since 2022).
- Skin is tied to one general—if that general is weak, you must pick power or eye-candy.
- Pick-rate manipulation also guts skin visibility.
- Extra fabric is added to please Chinese regulators; Steam version kept the censorship, no “uncensored patch” for overseas males.


Creativity is zero.

After copying Bang!, they never expanded mechanisms; they just print more generals with bigger numbers.

They once prototyped “Nation-War”: hidden generals, dual-general combos, history-based synergy—brilliant, but abandoned because it is harder to monetise.

Occasional PVE events shine, yet they stay side dishes; the main course is always “how to squeeze more”.

Even skill design is lazy. Since 2011 the “一将成名” contest let players submit ideas; 99 % of genius player designs are buried—too obscure, too original, or threaten the devs’ ego. What ships is mediocre, bug-safe, wallet-safe.


Community & dev attitude: radio silence.

- PC full-screen—missing.
- Sound drops—unfixed.
- Five-year-old tutorial—unchanged.
- UI misaligned—ignored.

Are these technically impossible for top-school hires? No, nobody cares; salary is flat, pressure is zero.

Paying customers who meet game-breaking bugs are ghosted like the rest.

Player rights—information, feedback, compensation—do not exist. To them we are wallets with fingers.


I could go on about the AI catastrophe, but enough.

If you still enjoy this game, you might want to explore player-created open-source projects related to it. Through fan creations, you can gain a clearer understanding of how much the official developers prioritize the actual gaming experience. You can also freely access powerful characters—often requiring over three hundred RMB to obtain in the official game—alongside more outstanding works designed by players themselves.

An IP that once thrilled me has become a slot machine wearing a Three-Kingdoms coat.

Count thy sins-Dogka, thou hast shamed the grace thy forebears gave.

I have nothing left to say—this is where I get off.


在我喋喋不休前，先简要说明一下就我目前发现的Steam服的《三国杀》存在的问题：
1. 完全就是《三国杀：一将成名》，没有适配PC全屏。
2. 新手教程一成不变，一如既往的冗长且没有更精细的讲解。
3. UI更新得更丑了，并且还没有适配新手教程，其中对于敌人标记的指示位置还是错误的。
4. 游戏完全没有切到后台，但却经常存在背景音乐丢失的问题。
5. 作为一个半网页端项目，前端响应设计一般，最明显的就是当网络较差时可以多次点击“结束回合”按钮。
6. 在新手登录时长的任务中存在计时器异常的问题，需要重启才会刷新为正常。
7. 常用的与游戏经验无关的“好友”等功能也需要达到对应等级方可开启，无跳过新手教程的选项和处理逻辑。
8. AI太蠢，连忠反明跳身份都判断不出来；在本就反贼占优的对局里，身份排位的忠内AI完全不作为，只有主公快死的时候才会插手；武将技能的处理更是惨不忍睹，连白板的牌序都不明白更别提搭配技能了。

如果你仍然喜欢这款游戏，不妨尝试一下玩家自制的相关开源项目：《无名杀》(github.com/libnoname/noname)和以联机为主的《新月杀》(github.com/Qsgs-Fans/FreeKill)。通过同人创作，你可以更加直观地认识到官方对真正的游戏体验投入占比有多低。

自2012年入坑后至今，它就一直在走下坡路。同一个IP完全一样的玩法、模式、卡牌，区别只有不同的侧重活动、角色技能、个别游戏机制的奇怪处理逻辑，其他的完全是换汤不换药，它竟然出了OL、移动版、海外服、十周年、欢乐、微信小程序以及其他形形色色的不太出名的渠道服，这么设计的主要目的只有一个——方便从同一名玩家身上尽最大可能榨干他的剩余价值。或许你会问“万一它想通过不同渠道来倾向性地选择用户或者针对性地测试问题呢？”前者或许有，但不多；后者那是不存在的，因为迄今为止各服先后有过各种恶性bug，至今也有些仍然存在但官方闭口不谈。下面容我做更详尽的叙述。

首先它的收益点就设计得很不合理，完全不是可持续发展的策略。收益最主要的部分是两个资源：武将和皮肤。但是作为一款回合制卡牌游戏，玩家取胜的概率主要由运气+角色强度+技巧组成，而它对前面二者基本垄断了，强力武将需要充值才能获取，不氪金的玩家只能投入大量的时间和精力去获取微薄的报酬，然后以月乃至年来计算才能得到一个强力武将。
正当你认为只要肯下功夫，哪怕有不多几个强力武将也可以坚持游玩时，它还可以通过以下方法让你的努力变得一文不值：
1. 新发布一个更加强力的武将，从数值上直接碾压原有的武将，或者单纯出一个专门克制你的武将，而这个武将需要充值或者大量的个人成本获取；
2. 降低你或者大多数0充值玩家持有的强力武将的出场率，毕竟每次游戏时都是从你所有拥有的武将里面“随机”抽取若干再由你选择，而“随机”完全是不透明的；

12 hours is the maximum amount of time I can play without recharging, including idle time. Before I ramble on, let me first list—briefly—the problems I’ve found so far with the Steam version of Legends of the Three Kingdoms (a.k.a. Sanguosha):

1. It is a 1-to-1 port of the Chinese mobile side-server “一将成名” (formerly the 10th-anniversary edition). No proper PC full-screen support.

3. The UI has been updated to something uglier, yet the tutorial still shows the old layout; enemy-indicator arrows point at the wrong places.
4. BGM often drops even though the game is never minimised.
5. As a half-web product, front-end responsiveness is mediocre: when the connection is bad you can spam the “End Turn” button and the server will accept every click.
6. The timer in the “new-player login-length” mission freezes; you must restart the client to refresh it.
7. Friends list, chat, and other non-gameplay functions are level-gated; there is no way to skip the tutorial.
8. AI is brain-dead: it cannot even tell loyalists from rebels; the “traitor” idles until the lord is dying; skill usage is catastrophic—it does not know the correct order to play vanilla cards, let alone combine skills.

Since I started in 2012 this IP has rolled downhill non-stop. Same rules, same cards, same modes—only the gacha banners, power-creep generals and a few odd mechanics change. “Maybe they want A/B testing or segmented users?”—if any, very little; real bug-testing does not exist, because every build has carried the same catastrophic bugs for years, some still unfixed and unmentioned.


Monetisation is built to bleed, not sustain.

Money comes from two faucets: generals and skins.

1. Power is locked behind pay-walls. Free players grind months or years for one meta general.
2. Once you finally get it they:
	- Release a strictly-better cash general,
	- Lower your general’s pick-rate through opaque “random” selection,
	- Rig the card deck so your key cards appear below probability.

3. Skill is meaningless when raw numbers crush you; unpaid players are Zhuge Liang six-sortie-ing from Qishan—great ambition, zero capital.

Skins sell even harder—some borderline-erotic female skins out-earn the strongest general of the season. Yet:

- Quality is uneven and homogenised (AI-art suspicion since 2022).
- Skin is tied to one general—if that general is weak, you must pick power or eye-candy.
- Pick-rate manipulation also guts skin visibility.
- Extra fabric is added to please Chinese regulators; Steam version kept the censorship, no “uncensored patch” for overseas males.


Creativity is zero.

After copying Bang!, they never expanded mechanisms; they just print more generals with bigger numbers.

They once prototyped “Nation-War”: hidden generals, dual-general combos, history-based synergy—brilliant, but abandoned because it is harder to monetise.

Occasional PVE events shine, yet they stay side dishes; the main course is always “how to squeeze more”.

Even skill design is lazy. Since 2011 the “一将成名” contest let players submit ideas; 99 % of genius player designs are buried—too obscure, too original, or threaten the devs’ ego. What ships is mediocre, bug-safe, wallet-safe.


Community & dev attitude: radio silence.

- PC full-screen—missing.
- Sound drops—unfixed.
- Five-year-old tutorial—unchanged.
- UI misaligned—ignored.

Are these technically impossible for top-school hires? No, nobody cares; salary is flat, pressure is zero.

Paying customers who meet game-breaking bugs are ghosted like the rest.

Player rights—information, feedback, compensation—do not exist. To them we are wallets with fingers.


I could go on about the AI catastrophe, but enough.

If you still enjoy this game, you might want to explore player-created open-source projects related to it. Through fan creations, you can gain a clearer understanding of how much the official developers prioritize the actual gaming experience. You can also freely access powerful characters—often requiring over three hundred RMB to obtain in the official game—alongside more outstanding works designed by players themselves.

An IP that once thrilled me has become a slot machine wearing a Three-Kingdoms coat.

Count thy sins-Dogka, thou hast shamed the grace thy forebears gave.

I have nothing left to say—this is where I get off.

12 hours is the maximum amount of time I can play without recharging, including idle time. Before I ramble on, let me first list—briefly—the problems I’ve found so far with the Steam version of Legends of the Three Kingdoms (a.k.a. Sanguosha):

1. It is a 1-to-1 port of the Chinese mobile side-server “一将成名” (formerly the 10th-anniversary edition). No proper PC full-screen support.
2. The newbie tutorial is still the one I saw five years ago—wordy, draggy, and with no finer explanations added.
3. The UI has been updated to something uglier, yet the tutorial still shows the old layout; enemy-indicator arrows point at the wrong places.
4. BGM often drops even though the game is never minimised.
5. As a half-web product, front-end responsiveness is mediocre: when the connection is bad you can spam the “End Turn” button and the server will accept every click.
6. The timer in the “new-player login-length” mission freezes; you must restart the client to refresh it.
7. Friends list, chat, and other non-gameplay functions are level-gated; there is no way to skip the tutorial.
8. AI is brain-dead: it cannot even tell loyalists from rebels; the “traitor” idles until the lord is dying; skill usage is catastrophic—it does not know the correct order to play vanilla cards, let alone combine skills.
9. Ranked queues are so empty that the matchmaker stuffs bots in, turning a sure win into a clown-fiesta defeat. No opt-out button. If there are not enough rookies, the game feeds paying customers brain-dead AIs and calls it “fun”. Even as a VIP I cannot squeeze any joy out of it.


Since I started in 2012 this IP has rolled downhill non-stop. Same rules, same cards, same modes—only the gacha banners, power-creep generals and a few odd mechanics change. They keep spawning OL edition, Mobile, Global, 10th-Anniversary (this one), “Happy” mini-game, We-chat mini, and a dozen obscure channel-servers—all aimed at milking the same cow dry.

“Maybe they want A/B testing or segmented users?”—if any, very little; real bug-testing does not exist, because every build has carried the same catastrophic bugs for years, some still unfixed and unmentioned.


Monetisation is built to bleed, not sustain.

Money comes from two faucets: generals and skins.

1. Power is locked behind pay-walls. Free players grind months or years for one meta general.
2. Once you finally get it they:
	- Release a strictly-better cash general,
	- Lower your general’s pick-rate through opaque “random” selection,
	- Rig the card deck so your key cards appear below probability.

3. Skill is meaningless when raw numbers crush you; unpaid players are Zhuge Liang six-sortie-ing from Qishan—great ambition, zero capital.

- UI misaligned—ignored.

Are these technically impossible for top-school hires? No, nobody cares; salary is flat, pressure is zero.

Paying customers who meet game-breaking bugs are ghosted like the rest.

Player rights—information, feedback, compensation—do not exist. To them we are wallets with fingers.

An IP that once thrilled me has become a slot machine wearing a Three-Kingdoms coat.

Count thy sins-Dogka, thou hast shamed the grace thy forebears gave.

12 hours is the maximum amount of time I can play without recharging, including idle time. Before I ramble on, let me first list—briefly—the problems I’ve found so far with the Steam version of Legends of the Three Kingdoms (a.k.a. Sanguosha):

1. It is a 1-to-1 port of the Chinese mobile side-server “一将成名” (formerly the 10th-anniversary edition). No proper PC full-screen support.
2. The newbie tutorial is still the one I saw five years ago—wordy, draggy, and with no finer explanations added.
3. The UI has been updated to something uglier, yet the tutorial still shows the old layout; enemy-indicator arrows point at the wrong places.
4. BGM often drops even though the game is never minimised.
5. As a half-web product, front-end responsiveness is mediocre: when the connection is bad you can spam the “End Turn” button and the server will accept every click.
6. The timer in the “new-player login-length” mission freezes; you must restart the client to refresh it.
7. Friends list, chat, and other non-gameplay functions are level-gated; there is no way to skip the tutorial.
8. AI is brain-dead: it cannot even tell loyalists from rebels; the “traitor” idles until the lord is dying; skill usage is catastrophic—it does not know the correct order to play vanilla cards, let alone combine skills.
9. Ranked queues are so empty that the matchmaker stuffs bots in, turning a sure win into a clown-fiesta defeat. No opt-out button. If there are not enough rookies, the game feeds paying customers brain-dead AIs and calls it “fun”. Even as a VIP I cannot squeeze any joy out of it.


Since I started in 2012 this IP has rolled downhill non-stop. Same rules, same cards, same modes—only the gacha banners, power-creep generals and a few odd mechanics change. They keep spawning OL edition, Mobile, Global, 10th-Anniversary (this one), “Happy” mini-game, We-chat mini, and a dozen obscure channel-servers—all aimed at milking the same cow dry.

“Maybe they want A/B testing or segmented users?”—if any, very little; real bug-testing does not exist, because every build has carried the same catastrophic bugs for years, some still unfixed and unmentioned.


Monetisation is built to bleed, not sustain.

Money comes from two faucets: generals and skins.

1. Power is locked behind pay-walls. Free players grind months or years for one meta general.
2. Once you finally get it they:
	- Release a strictly-better cash general,
	- Lower your general’s pick-rate through opaque “random” selection,
	- Rig the card deck so your key cards appear below probability.

3. Skill is meaningless when raw numbers crush you; unpaid players are Zhuge Liang six-sortie-ing from Qishan—great ambition, zero capital.

Skins sell even harder—some borderline-erotic female skins out-earn the strongest general of the season. Yet:

- Quality is uneven and homogenised (AI-art suspicion since 2022).
- Skin is tied to one general—if that general is weak, you must pick power or eye-candy.
- Pick-rate manipulation also guts skin visibility.
- Extra fabric is added to please Chinese regulators; Steam version kept the censorship, no “uncensored patch” for overseas males.


Creativity is zero.

After copying Bang!, they never expanded mechanisms; they just print more generals with bigger numbers.

They once prototyped “Nation-War”: hidden generals, dual-general combos, history-based synergy—brilliant, but abandoned because it is harder to monetise.

Occasional PVE events shine, yet they stay side dishes; the main course is always “how to squeeze more”.

Even skill design is lazy. Since 2011 the “一将成名” contest let players submit ideas; 99 % of genius player designs are buried—too obscure, too original, or threaten the devs’ ego. What ships is mediocre, bug-safe, wallet-safe.


Community & dev attitude: radio silence.

- PC full-screen—missing.
- Sound drops—unfixed.
- Five-year-old tutorial—unchanged.
- UI misaligned—ignored.

Are these technically impossible for top-school hires? No, nobody cares; salary is flat, pressure is zero.

Paying customers who meet game-breaking bugs are ghosted like the rest.

Player rights—information, feedback, compensation—do not exist. To them we are wallets with fingers.


I could go on about the AI catastrophe, but enough.

If you still enjoy this game, you might want to explore player-created open-source projects related to it. Through fan creations, you can gain a clearer understanding of how much the official developers prioritize the actual gaming experience. You can also freely access powerful characters—often requiring over three hundred RMB to obtain in the official game—alongside more outstanding works designed by players themselves.

An IP that once thrilled me has become a slot machine wearing a Three-Kingdoms coat.

Count thy sins-Dogka, thou hast shamed the grace thy forebears gave.

I have nothing left to say—this is where I get off.

2. 降低你或者大多数0充值玩家持有的强力武将的出场率，毕竟每次游戏时都是从你所有拥有的武将里面“随机”抽取若干再由你选择，而“随机”完全是不透明的；
3. 暗中操控卡牌堆，让你持有的武将的key牌概率明显低于数学期望，这种方法也是控制你“运气”的常用伎俩。

角色的皮肤也是游戏盈利最主要的途径之一，一些擦边的女性武将的皮肤创造的收益甚至高于可以在当时环境下担当“全服最强”的武将本身。然而有以下几点不建议你为此将金钱投入其中：
1. 质量层次不齐且同质化严重。虽然没有确凿的证据断定画师或者游戏官方美工人员使用了AI，但自从AI绘画问世后，皮肤的同质化现象愈发严重。

1. 大海捞针，没处寻。很多精美的设计可能由于设计者并不出名，被海选的机器洗刷掉了；
2. 望文兴叹，心生妒。一些评委可能由于自己对设计质量的评判标准存在差异，或可能因为这份设计用到了自己想到的一个好点子而不想让这个想法被他人占有，亦或者受官方类似“每个创新点必须由官方的设计师率先发布上线”的原因被尘封，当然也包括设计者想法很好，但自己没有表达清楚产生二义性或者其他误会，最终被海选筛掉；

首先它的收益点就设计得很不合理，完全不是可持续发展的策略。收益最主要的部分是两个资源：武将和皮肤。但是作为一款回合制卡牌游戏，玩家取胜的概率主要由运气+角色强度+技巧组成，而它对前面二者基本垄断了，强力武将需要充值才能获取，不氪金的玩家只能投入大量的时间和精力去获取微薄的报酬，然后以月乃至年来计算才能得到一个强力武将。
正当你认为只要肯下功夫，哪怕有不多几个强力武将也可以坚持游玩时，它还可以通过以下方法让你的努力变得一文不值：
1. 新发布一个更加强力的武将，从数值上直接碾压原有的武将，或者单纯出一个专门克制你的武将，而这个武将需要充值或者大量的个人成本获取；

3. 暗中操控卡牌堆，让你持有的武将的key牌概率明显低于数学期望，这种方法也是控制你“运气”的常用伎俩。

而最后一点你能主动掌握的“技巧”，很抱歉，在目前的环境下，如果你不充值的话，甚至连利用“技巧”的资格都没有，因为对于数值上的单纯碾压，你再好的技巧都像是六出祁山的诸葛亮，空有抱负但无足以支撑雄心的资本。
角色的皮肤也是游戏盈利最主要的途径之一，一些擦边的女性武将的皮肤创造的收益甚至高于可以在当时环境下担当“全服最强”的武将本身。然而有以下几点不建议你为此将金钱投入其中：
1. 质量层次不齐且同质化严重。虽然没有确凿的证据断定画师或者游戏官方美工人员使用了AI，但自从AI绘画问世后，皮肤的同质化现象愈发严重。
2. 皮肤是基于武将的。这就意味着如果这个武将本身强度一般，那你必须从“强度”和“美术体验”中二选一。
3. 同前面，武将出场率是可以被暗中控制的，对应皮肤的对局出场率也会受到牵连。

其次就是游戏的创新性也十分匮乏。它沿袭了《Bang!》的模式和机制后，并没有如同后者那样将方向定位于更多的机制和花样上，而是朝着“武将”这一最容易实现的道路一去不返。当然武将不断创新技能点也是很有想法的，当然它并没有那样做，那样太费脑子了，还是数值来得轻松直白，数值不够你想要赢必须得充值，多么浅显的逻辑。

回到武将的设计上，技能的设计也是可以精斟细酌的，当然官方的设计师似乎不太给力。从2011年开始，名为“一将成名”的全民武将设计征集就在举办，许多富有水平和想象力的设计多源于此。自此，武将设计水平的大旗似乎就移交给了热忱的玩家，但最终能放到端游内真正体验的却是官方设计的中庸武将居多，玩家的精彩设计主要由于包括但不限于以下情况被筛掉：
1. 大海捞针，没处寻。很多精美的设计可能由于设计者并不出名，被海选的机器洗刷掉了；
2. 望文兴叹，心生妒。一些评委可能由于自己对设计质量的评判标准存在差异，或可能因为这份设计用到了自己想到的一个好点子而不想让这个想法被他人占有，亦或者受官方类似“每个创新点必须由官方的设计师率先发布上线”的原因被尘封，当然也包括设计者想法很好，但自己没有表达清楚产生二义性或者其他误会，最终被海选筛掉；

AI也是一个巨大的问题，这里就不再赘述了。

12 hours is the maximum amount of time I can play without recharging, including idle time. Before I ramble on, let me first list—briefly—the problems I’ve found so far with the Steam version of Legends of the Three Kingdoms (a.k.a. Sanguosha):

1. It is a 1-to-1 port of the Chinese mobile side-server “一将成名” (formerly the 10th-anniversary edition). No proper PC full-screen support.
2. The newbie tutorial is still the one I saw five years ago—wordy, draggy, and with no finer explanations added.
3. The UI has been updated to something uglier, yet the tutorial still shows the old layout; enemy-indicator arrows point at the wrong places.
4. BGM often drops even though the game is never minimised.
5. As a half-web product, front-end responsiveness is mediocre: when the connection is bad you can spam the “End Turn” button and the server will accept every click.
6. The timer in the “new-player login-length” mission freezes; you must restart the client to refresh it.
7. Friends list, chat, and other non-gameplay functions are level-gated; there is no way to skip the tutorial.
8. AI is brain-dead: it cannot even tell loyalists from rebels; the “traitor” idles until the lord is dying; skill usage is catastrophic—it does not know the correct order to play vanilla cards, let alone combine skills.
9. Ranked queues are so empty that the matchmaker stuffs bots in, turning a sure win into a clown-fiesta defeat. No opt-out button. If there are not enough rookies, the game feeds paying customers brain-dead AIs and calls it “fun”. Even as a VIP I cannot squeeze any joy out of it.


Since I started in 2012 this IP has rolled downhill non-stop. Same rules, same cards, same modes—only the gacha banners, power-creep generals and a few odd mechanics change. They keep spawning OL edition, Mobile, Global, 10th-Anniversary (this one), “Happy” mini-game, We-chat mini, and a dozen obscure channel-servers—all aimed at milking the same cow dry.

“Maybe they want A/B testing or segmented users?”—if any, very little; real bug-testing does not exist, because every build has carried the same catastrophic bugs for years, some still unfixed and unmentioned.


Monetisation is built to bleed, not sustain.

Money comes from two faucets: generals and skins.

1. Power is locked behind pay-walls. Free players grind months or years for one meta general.
2. Once you finally get it they:
	- Release a strictly-better cash general,
	- Lower your general’s pick-rate through opaque “random” selection,
	- Rig the card deck so your key cards appear below probability.

3. Skill is meaningless when raw numbers crush you; unpaid players are Zhuge Liang six-sortie-ing from Qishan—great ambition, zero capital.

Skins sell even harder—some borderline-erotic female skins out-earn the strongest general of the season. Yet:

- Quality is uneven and homogenised (AI-art suspicion since 2022).
- Skin is tied to one general—if that general is weak, you must pick power or eye-candy.
- Pick-rate manipulation also guts skin visibility.
- Extra fabric is added to please Chinese regulators; Steam version kept the censorship, no “uncensored patch” for overseas males.


Creativity is zero.

After copying Bang!, they never expanded mechanisms; they just print more generals with bigger numbers.

They once prototyped “Nation-War”: hidden generals, dual-general combos, history-based synergy—brilliant, but abandoned because it is harder to monetise.

Occasional PVE events shine, yet they stay side dishes; the main course is always “how to squeeze more”.

Even skill design is lazy. Since 2011 the “一将成名” contest let players submit ideas; 99 % of genius player designs are buried—too obscure, too original, or threaten the devs’ ego. What ships is mediocre, bug-safe, wallet-safe.


Community & dev attitude: radio silence.

- PC full-screen—missing.
- Sound drops—unfixed.
- Five-year-old tutorial—unchanged.
- UI misaligned—ignored.

Are these technically impossible for top-school hires? No, nobody cares; salary is flat, pressure is zero.

Paying customers who meet game-breaking bugs are ghosted like the rest.

Player rights—information, feedback, compensation—do not exist. To them we are wallets with fingers.


I could go on about the AI catastrophe, but enough.

If you still enjoy this game, you might want to explore player-created open-source projects related to it. Through fan creations, you can gain a clearer understanding of how much the official developers prioritize the actual gaming experience. You can also freely access powerful characters—often requiring over three hundred RMB to obtain in the official game—alongside more outstanding works designed by players themselves.

An IP that once thrilled me has become a slot machine wearing a Three-Kingdoms coat.

Count thy sins-Dogka, thou hast shamed the grace thy forebears gave.

I have nothing left to say—this is where I get off.

曾经它也设计了更契合历史（按武将的势力划分）、具有独创性玩法（暗置武将，不直接暴露玩家的身份和技能；双武将设计，可以搭配不同的组合；珠联璧合效果，历史上关系匪浅的人物有额外加成和搭配技巧）的“国战”模式；也不乏偶尔会出现让人眼前一亮的PVE模式，但它并没有将这些作为自己的主线任务，毕竟它的主线任务只有一个——怎么能从同一名玩家身上尽最大可能榨干他的剩余价值。有不少人游玩还是为了这些模式，但这些模式的发掘又还剩多少？
回到武将的设计上，技能的设计也是可以精斟细酌的，当然官方的设计师似乎不太给力。从2011年开始，名为“一将成名”的全民武将设计征集就在举办，许多富有水平和想象力的设计多源于此。自此，武将设计水平的大旗似乎就移交给了热忱的玩家，但最终能放到端游内真正体验的却是官方设计的中庸武将居多，玩家的精彩设计主要由于包括但不限于以下情况被筛掉：
1. 大海捞针，没处寻。很多精美的设计可能由于设计者并不出名，被海选的机器洗刷掉了；
2. 望文兴叹，心生妒。一些评委可能由于自己对设计质量的评判标准存在差异，或可能因为这份设计用到了自己想到的一个好点子而不想让这个想法被他人占有，亦或者受官方类似“每个创新点必须由官方的设计师率先发布上线”的原因被尘封，当然也包括设计者想法很好，但自己没有表达清楚产生二义性或者其他误会，最终被海选筛掉；
3. 力所不及，空欢喜。即使武将最终过审采纳了，还存在对代码和机制的影响上。一些天马行空的设计可能在代码上难以实现，或者即使实现了也会引发各种冲突甚至恶性bug，其中也包括对现有机制体系的冲击，需要花更长的时间去定义和处理与原有机制的交互和冲突优先级。

然而，因为技能设计上的思维争辩和机制问题已经开始式微，因为随着时代的变迁，游戏的更迭，玩家对于这些更深层次的讨论和考量已经越来越少，曾经可被认为资深的玩家已经失去耐心，退坑或者将更多精力转向其他相较而言值得游玩的游戏了。尽管设计大赛仍在举办，但设计都开始朝着同质的数值、简单技能堆砌方面开始倾向，鲜有人能提出大胆的设计想法了。此外还有许多充斥着对游戏的不满，以此为情感宣泄口的难以称为“设计”的设计。不充值的人只能靠为数不多的逆风局得到快感，充值的人因为投入了更多的成本和精力而对队友愈发苛责，愈发乌烟瘴气的游戏环境也是这个游戏体验如此差的原因之一。

再有就是官方对玩家和问题的态度。只能说几乎是完全不管不顾，哪怕你是大量充值的玩家，对于他们无能为力的恶性bug他们就是集体装死。bug真的难以修复吗？问题真的无法解决吗？那从最直观的问题说起，它为什么至今都没有适配PC全屏？它为什么连没有切屏的音效问题都没有修复？它为什么连早已过时的新手教程都不舍得更换一套？它为什么连早就修改的UI效果都没有适配？这些真的难到高薪聘请来的名校学生都无法解决吗？还是能将就罢了，工资反正就那些，人不施加压力就是惰性的。连这些直接影响玩家体验的东西都置之不理，我不觉得它会在思想上还有什么觉悟。
